Authors:
Mingliang Yin, Michael J Wingfield, Riikka Linnakoski,
XuDong Zhou, Z. Wilhelm de Beer
Title:
Taxonomy and phylogeny of the Leptographium olivaceum complex
(Ophiostomatales, Ascomycota), including descriptions of six new species
from China and Europe
Keywords:
bark beetle associates, epitype, Leptographium,
Grosmannia, Ophiostomatales, phylogeny, taxonomy.
Abstract:
The Grosmannia olivacea complex encompasses species in the
broadly defined genus Leptographium sensu lato (Ophiostomatales,
Ascomycota) that are generally characterized by synnematous
conidiospores. The complex includes six species, most of which are
associates of conifer-infesting bark beetles in Europe and North
America. The aims of this study were to reconsider the delineation of
these six species, and to confirm the identity of several additional
isolates resembling G. olivacea that have emerged from recent surveys in
Poland, Finland, Russia, Spain and China. Phylogenetic analyses of
sequence data for five gene regions (ITS2-LSU, actin, β-tubulin, CAL,
and TEF-1α) distinguished 14 taxa. These included eight known species:
G. olivacea, G. cucullata, G. davidsonii, G. olivaceapini, G.
sagmatospora, G. vesca, L. erubescens, and L. francke-grosmanniae. The
last one species formed a group that was phylogenetically,
morphologically and ecologically distinct from the remaining species in
the complex. The recent collections included six new species herein
described as L. pseudoalbum, L. conplurium, L. pigmentoconidium, L.
poloniae, L. rhizoidum, and L. breviuscapa. A new combination is
provided for L. erubescens, and lectotypes are designated for this
species as well as for G. olivacea and G. sagmatospora. Epitypes were
also designated for these three species as well as G. olivaceapini. In
addition to phylogenetic separation, the synnematous asexual states and
ascomata with almost cylindrical necks and prominent ostiolar hyphae,
distinguish the G. olivacea complex from others in Leptographium s. l.
It is conceivable that this complex represents a distinct genus in the
Ophiostomatales for which the name Phialographium would be available but
additional studies should be undertaken before this issue is
resolved.
